 750 mL bottle.  No bottle date to be found.   The bleak western-drabness of its stickered label actually made it stand out with me. It was so glaringly simple yet the choice of playful colors (red, black, and light beige) was stunningly meticulous as to how they were used.  To red wine glass, it pours a cloudy light orange that a snowy white head attached itself up on. Wonderful.  The aroma is an assault of tropical fruit sexiness, springtime flowers, and sourdough yeast starters. I managed to retrieve guava, dried mangoes, canned pineapple juice, fresh sourdough, clementine zest, and wheat upon taking my first few sniffs. All sensations remained unbearably the same even after the 10 minute mark, though a touch of algae, soured milk, farmhouse yeast, and peas did oversee some small part of action lingering in the back.  Altogether flavor is what I could best describe as "cocktail-in nature": expensive champagne, orange and clementine juice, table sugar, dry bitters, and lime. This almost perfectly represents the mimosa. I havent tried Hill Farmsteads glorious attempt, but I can only guess its just as good - though Id probably reckon that there would be an overabundance of orange juice in the flavor. This one doesnt really have much tropical sting aside from whats riding in the background faintly muttering out of the loud choruses of funk, champagne, and pale malts. Rice malt experienced alongside sweat, crushed coriander, pea water, wildflower honey,and noble hops convincingly at swallow.  An inventively sturdy sour milkiness hides a barely-existing alcohol heat in its maltose bosom, burning bright and massive, until my next sip. Lavender only merely hinted at after its swallow.  This is a fantastic saison: just as good as anything Ive had from HF.  I may have been wondering if the abv was higher while I was on a half-glass of this beauty, because feeling the burn was an inevitable occurrence. It wasnt potent, but certainly wouldnt be misremembered. 
 Age this on fruit and you will have the best sasion the world has ever known.

750mL bottle shared with Blisscent at Hill Farmstead on 8/11/16.Huge white head is well-retained and tops a lightly hazy, deep blonde-golden body.Minerality is high in the nose, with gentle acidity and mild yogurt-like suggestions, but no one yeast/bacteria note dominating. Lemon character grows strong, with lots of peppery phenol and light fruitiness from the hops, but again not dominated by either hop flavor or acidity. Malts add biscuit, strong honey and just a pinch of caramel and it all comes off very well-integrated with no alcohol or flaw.Very soft, malty texture shows ample, tight carbonation and good attenuation overall. Quite big on the mineral character with even some strong salinity that takes the edge of any potential hop bitterness and softens the acidity produced by the mixed culture. This creates a bit more perceived sweetness than I think is actually here and really highlights both malt/grain character as well as the esters from the yeast. Some tartness still emerges on the finish, inevitably and it never comes off too sweet, some light oak tannin dryness helping to see to that, as well. Not much of a hop footprint here, which I like, but the mixed culture still sees it straddling line between traditional saison and American sour ale (despite it not being sour). Love the minerality/salinity. Not the most complex saison, but very enjoyable and drinkable nonetheless.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2016 Bottle from Carl (spacecoyote) -- cheers! Opened as part of a larger tasting not expecting anything in particular, but this one floored me. Its close to the perfect saison in my opinion -- theres a sour touch thats noticeable but not overpowering, a great yeast character that is peppery but subtle, and a fantastic water profile that blends the yeast, malt, and hops together beautifully. Its not only one of the best saisons Ive ever had, its easily one of the best beers Ive ever had.

Draft at the brewery. Pours a hazy gold on the lighter end of the spectrum and a small white head that settles into a bubbly rign and faint film that leaves spots of lace in the glass. Notes of lemon, white wine, oak, berady malts, straw, pears, and some light, bright bretty funk. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a tart, floral, lightly funky mouthfeel. Great saison. Excellent stuff for any time.

From notes. This was shared at Dougs Poker/Beer/Cigar party on February 13. 750 mL bottle. The pour is a nice foggy golden straw color with a nice white head that falls down, leaving some awesome lace. The aroma is really lice. There is a huge lemon tartness up front, backed up by a nice raspberry and apple skin. There is a little bit of fleshy peach and then into some bretty funk. This smells incredible. The fact that Im not a saison guy and I like this should be all that needs be said. The flavor is also really good. There is a little wheat up front to go with a light funk, but then it kicks into a lemon tartness and that same fleshy peach. There is a hint of the brett funk on the back end, but its very balanced, and really good. The mouth feel is light and crisp. Nicely dry, with a good carbonation. Its got a strong funk on the back end that I could do without, but its really good. I might try to get some more of this.

Half pour

4/VII/15 - 75cl bottle @ RBBSG IV - BB: n/a (2015-835)  Thanks to JefVerstraete for sharing the bottle!
Pretty cloudy yellow beer, small aery white head, little stable, non adhesive. Aroma: sourish, funky, fruity, peaches. MF: ok carbon, medium to light body. Taste: sourish, citrus, very fruity, funky, soft bitterness, some tannins. Aftertaste: very fruity, peaches, citrus, lemony, bit funky. Is it a saison? Nope. this is a very nice fruity US sour.

Bottle thanks to Errl! Aromas are lemon juice, berries, musty hay and oak. Tastes both tart and sweet. Very little sourness. So easy to slam. Really good and easy to drink but also nothing really to make it stand out as a top 5 saison.

Dégustée au RBBSG 15 chez Tim. Cheers! Bière blonde, trouble avec un simple anneau blanc en guise de mousse. Nez de Brettanomyces, alcool léger et beaucoup de fruits frais tels la pêche et labricot. Très effervescente en bouche qui confère une impressionnante minéralisé et légèreté au liquide. Le parfum de pêche est encore plus puissant en bouche quau nez. Cest pétillant, fruité, minéral, scintillant! Corps moyen, peu de sucre et longue en bouche, sans arrière-goût ni amertume apparente. Un très gros coup de coeur pour tous les convives présents.
Huge floral tartness in the aromas. Pearlescent golden yellow with thick tiny bubble head. Smooth tart flowers pull you to a slight vinager then rounds to a perfect sour.
Bottle from a trade. Many thanks! Hazy amber/orange colour. Sweet nose of peach, citrus (oranges and lemon). Tart flavour, notes of brett. Not overly sour but very well balanced. Very good!

Thanks to JefVerstraete! 750 ml. bottle sampled @ Hot & Sweaty RBBSG 2015. Hazy orange, small white head. Nose is boozy fermenting apricot, peach, stone fruit nose, akin to faintly alcoholic overly ripe fruits, rustic, lots of overripe fruits, oak, white grape, some brett, faint citrus sour, Taste is same boozy stone fruit, boozy peach, oak, brett, tad too high carbonation, mild acidity in the finish, more of the same fruits, faint aspirin, peach, faint boozy esters, faint fermented, some lemon acidity, Body is faintly prickling, tad too high carb. Fermenting boozy fruits dominate a bit too much to my liking. That is a personal preference, others went crazy for this beer.
Bottle at RBBSG, thanks for sharing JefVerstraete. Peaches, grapes, nice sour, some bitterness but might be the last of the bottle. Good.

P: A hazy golden color with almost no head. S: Limes with some brett, a bit of oak and stone fruits. T: Like kiwis, a bit of papaya, citrus some cucumber with a touch of brett. M: Light and puckery, soft on the palate. O: Very nice, a bit different but in a very delicious way.
Yellow to golden with white head. Fruity with yellow fuits and little citrus. Light sour, spicy and brett
Bottle, pour is clear yellow low head. Aroma is light funk and big oak and grape. Tastes like a tart white wine
Delicious. Just as simple as that. This time Im drinking bottle #3 (that i am rating) in a paper cup aquired from an amtrak coffee kiosk.
750 ml bottle through club. Pours a hazy yellow. Nose is a wonderful funk followed by lemon notes. Big lemon notes. Yeasty. Really fantastic.

Courtesy of northernbrews
Bottle: The aroma of brett, sweet tarts, apple, light lemon peel, and a touch of spice. It pours a transparent gold with a small white head that quickly fades to a minimal film outlined by a thin ring. There is minimal lacing left on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with moderate peach and lighter citrus. The finish moderate sour lemon with a touch of sweet tarts, brett, and a touch of lemon peel. Its light bodied with light-moderate carbonation.
Bottle. Pours yellow gold white head. Nose and taste of sour lemongrass, funk, oak and wine- medium body

Bottle into an HF glass. Immediately upon opening it, I can smell loads of citrus. Pours a hazy yellowish color with a modest head. Smells of citrus, light Brett/barnyard notes, very lightly peppery. Wonderful citrus-forward flavor. Tastes of lemon; lightly tart. Carbonation is average, but lively on the tongue. Light+ bodied and dry. An absolutely wonderful saison.
Bottle. Pours cloudy pale golden with a small white head. Aroma is funky citric fruity grassy a bit rustic, very elegant. Flavor is Crisp sour granne citric lemon juice very light texturer, soo god.
Shared bottle. Pours a cloudy pale gold with a small white head. Aroma of fruit, citrus, and funk. Taste is lemon, tropical, peach, funk, and spice. Somewhat tart. Excellent.

Sample at the beer cellar, thanks Dave. Tart and quite sour for a saison, even more so than the HF line. Lemon and citrus, earthy, and straw. Some brett funk and spiciness. Pretty good blend of sour and barnyard. very carbonated, the bottle was a gusher. Dry crisp finish.
Hazy yellow orange in color... Aroma of hay, grains, light citrus.... Pour is effervescent, bright nose... Flavor is tart and lemon citrus... Grains, bready notes... Great beer
Where the Wild Beers Are, 2014. Very good. P think there is brett and lacto yeast. This is dry, earthy, and a little sour. Gold color, well carbonated. Excellent saison.

Bottle, batch 8. Pours glowing, lightly cloudy pale peach with small head that subsides to lacing. Aroma is just so balanced and complex, with wild yeast, tropical fruit, bright citrus, grain, earthy and grassy hops, and spice all mingling together. Tons of peach and orange, white wine, lemon, faint sulfur. Taste is bright orange fading into grain, faint banana, spice, light phenols, white wine, slight sulfur. Manages to be crisp and light while still full. A benchmark beer for the style. Love.

750ml bottle thanks to bytemesis! Pours opaque orange with a finger of head. Nose is juicy peach, tangerine, tart stonefruit with a soft bit of barny grain. Taste is bursting with stonefruit and tropical fruits, tart tangerine, nectarine and peach, absolutely perfect level or tartness. Finish is more juicy fruit and citrus with ever so subtle rustic grain and farm hay. Very low funk. Fantastic.

Bottle from chebyshev, shared for the joint 12K tasting. Hazy yellow with white head. Funky sourness, fresh citrus, peach, pizza dough yeast, wet hay, bretty, high carbonation and moderate body, dry and crisp on the finish with a nice combination of yeast, tart and fruit.
Cloudy medium yellow with a good white head. Aroma is lemon peel, brett funk, orange blossom. Light bodied, mildly tart on the palate, refreshing and well balanced with a slightly dry finish.
Tap, gold pour, white head, nose is grassy, taste is lemon, pepper, funky, amazing
Sampled via bottle at WTWBA 2014 in Minneapolis. Killer beer. Hazy yellow pour. Citrus with some Brett funkiness. So freaking good.

Bottle: Poured a cloudy straw color ale with a nice huge foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of tart and dry Bretty notes is quiet funky. Taste is also a mix of dry Bretty notes with some barnyard notes easily noticeable with a tart finish. Body is quite full with great carbonation. Very enjoyable beer but not even sure this is a saison any more considering the amount of funky and tart notes that can be tasted.

Pours cloudy straw lots of head and lots of lacing. Nose is tart peach, dough. Flavours of tart peach, dough and Cheerios. Tastes medium tart, light sweet. Medium sticky body with dry finish. Great beer, thanks guys!

Tap. Moderate to heavy grain, hay and light bread for the malt, moderate flowers and grass for the hops, moderate wet concrete for the yeast, with a note of peach in the bckground. Head is average size, white with spotty lacing and good legs. Color is hazy yellow. Flavor starts harshly acidic and sour, then finishes heavily acidic, moderately bitter and sour. Palate is light, watery, with a fizzy carbonation and a tart finish. This beer is verging on a Sour Ale but theres not enough dankness. This is a superb Saison.

A lightly hazed golden saison with a thin white head. In aroma, sweet lemony malt with light grassy hops, acidity, OK. In mouth, a nice sweet fruity malt with nice lemon juice, perfumy notes, light talcum, light salty notes, very nice.

Draft at Sante Adairius. Hazy blonde, small but persistent head. The initial spicy estery slightly acid aroma belies the sharpness of this beer. Further down the glass it smells more acid. Touch of sweet malt then lemony citrus acidity and some sharp grape, redcurrant, orange notes. Dry finish. Delicious, subtle and complex. Really nice.

Poured from 750, into a Barrelworks rastal teku glass. Hazy yellow gold with a minimal white head that quickly dissipated. Nose is a bit funky and fruity, taste is mildly sour, dry, and somewhat bitter. Nice dry finish.
Golden pour, frothy white head. Nose is tart lemon, citrus, brett. Taste is clean, crisp tart lemon, citrus. Dry and easy drinking.

On tap at Fofa, Pours a beautiful blond with thick white head. Aroma is white fruits, bretts, grass and delicate spices. Taste is moderatly sour, some cereal, citrus and white fruits. Refined and delicate, very good.

Bottle via unknown at de Garde Summer Gathering. Get the fuck out! Not at all traditional, but incredibly impressive. Pours a cloudy golden color, not much head, body cloudy and turbid. Aroma slightly funky, some Brett fruitiness, but the body, wow! So juicy and fresh, this is really remarkable. FInish is a lingering citrus bitterness, tart yet dry. Stellar, really.

75 cl bottle.
Pours cloudy yellow color with a small head. Lemon, herbs and yeast on the nose, some earthiness too. Sourish fruits, rowan berries, gooseberries and citrus on the flavor, some mild wooden notes too. A weird mix of a Saison and a Sour Ale. Tasty anyway.
3445

750 ml bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow colour with a small head. Aroma of fresh citrus, sorbus and freshly cut grass. Flavour of tart berries, sorbus, apricot, wood, brett and white bread. Mild lactic acid notes. Long sour finish. Far from the original Saison style, pretty close to a sour ale.

75 cl bottle @ tiong
Aroma has strong citrus notes. Also some tart, earthy notes and grapefruit. Flavour has strong lemon notes, grapefruit and lactic tones. Also some earthy tones typical to lambics on the flavour side  and sorbus. Not the most typical saison and rather weird but I seem to enjoy this. Could be a sour ale as well.

750ml bottle from Summer Secret Santa 2014, huge thanks to ineedbeer!
Pours orange with a smooth head. Aroma of tart bretta notes, funky yeastiness, ripe fruits, spices, earthy notes and grapefruit. Taste is grapefruity, funky yeasty and slightly sourish with notes of tart citrus, bretta and spicy vinegar. Finish is sourish, tartish and citrusy with notes of grapefruit and funky yeast, hints of bretta and vinegar. Quite complex, tasty and balanced sourish saison.

Bottle shared by yourefragile. Thanks Michael!

The beer is straw yellow and hazy with a bone white head. The aroma brings hay, grass, floral notes, lemon. Great flavor. Smooth on the palate with herbal notes, lemon. The finish is gentle, with minimal tartness. Sunshine in a glass. Tasty.
(FOFA 2014): Une belle saison agrumée et parfumée avec une irrésistible structure céréalière. Filiforme et élégante avec une finale sèche, légèrement acidulée.

This is it, perhaps the greatest beer I have had. The balance in this thing is beyond anything I have ever had. Moderately tart, fresh, carbonation is perfect, body is medium light, but it feels and drinks fresh. Funky, vibrant, absolutely delightful.

750 ml bottle shared by yourefragile, thanks Moll. Pours a hazy dark golden/near orange color with lasting off white edge head. Aroma is Brett yeast, bright citrus fruits with lemon and tangerine. Flavor is same with bright carbonation and dry sweet finish. Lasting tart citrus finish.

750ml bottle via trade with bytemesis. Pours a hazy gold with some sudsy white head. Nose is really lovely, lemony, like a lemon tea, yogurt, lacto, straw, mild perfume, some lime, some dried herbs. Flavor has this wonderful and refreshing tart lemon character, grass, straw, mild malt, cracker, herbs, perfume, lime, some mineral water. Lightly tannic, lightly tart finish.

Bottle: Thanks, Erik. Cloudy, pear-yellow body. Basically opaque, thick & juicy looking. White foam settles to a collar quickly. Aroma of light, sweaty funk, lemon-lime, damp hay, a bit of citric tartness. Nice Brett character, a good amount of sweaty barnyard & horsey funk towards the back-end, a little pineapple. Taste has more acidic & seemingly lacto tartness than expected, but thats not a bad thing at all. Lovely lemon, lime, citrus, & pineapple sour notes bust through. Big backing of rustic straw, grain, bready yeast, & a good layer of dusty cobweb funkiness. A little bit of woodiness in the finish, Im guessing thanks to the Brett. Lingering green apple tartness. An absolutely delicious beer!
Bottle shared at Kulminator by Dennoman - thanks Dennoman. Hmmm, the lacto and peppery yeast are strong in this one. mèh...

The only other thing thats worse
Is eating yeast spread on a toast...
Add my moms liqueur to it
Its the only way to get it fixed

Bottle share thanks to Homer321. Pours is clear, yellow color with large foamy white head. Aroma is bretty, tart, funky, citrusy. Tast ie really nice, smooth, mildly tart, citrusy, orange and light lemon. Very refreshing and yummy. Could drink a lot of this.

Bottle thanks to Mike! Nose is a moderate funk with some lemon and citrus. Pour is a slightly hazy yellow with a white head that laces well. Taste is a barny lemon and citrus blend of greatness. A pleasant honey malt presence with a drying finish. Nothing short of amazing.

Bottle share thanks to Homer321. mostly clear, straw yellow color with large foamy white head. Aroma is bretty, tart, funky, fruit juice - citrusy, light spicy phenols. Nice, smooth, mildly tart, brett, citrusy, orange and light lemon. Very refreshing.

With the crew. Hot damn this was a good saison tasting day. Light yellow color, little bit of a foamy gusher so watch out on opening this one. Spice and yeast in the aroma. Grassy herbal notes. Really good light fruit, lemon and banana. Nice balance and insane complexity.

Shared by ericteusink with the crew. On a day of crazy brews this one reigned supreme. Fantasically tart and dry, the berries, tart citrus, hint of funk, brett. Just a near perfect balance of everything.

Pours golden with a haze. The carbonation is high but lessened and the foamy head laced my glass. The aroma has a pleasant brett character with a mild tart scent. I also noticed a moderation of tangerine and lemon citrus with malts, and some wheat scents. In tasting I picked up on a puckered lemon flavor with a tangerine like tartness that followed. There was a nice blending of grain flavor, citrus, and pear with a mild to medium dryness in the finish. Overall this was a perfect marriage of ingredients and it is very refreshing. I would surely have this again if it presented itself.

On tap at the brewery. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of sourness and tartness, some pale malts, a light citrus note, and some dryness. Flavor a great blend. Average texture. A really good beer.

Bottle generously shared by Vinny. Pours glowing, vibrant sunshine with a spotty white head and lace. Nose is Granny Smith, fresh pear, rocks in clean rain, lemon pith, and dry oak barrels. Taste is lemon skin, grapefruit pith, tangy Spree candy, and tongue-drying tangerine. The experience of sipping this is like closing one's eyes and having a clean, dry, mineral-laden wave wash calmly over his tongue. I picture the wave washing up upon the shore if my tongue, the moisture saturating the porpoise sand, as the wave ebbs into the ocean once again, the dry salinity lifts up into the seabreeze of the next inhalation. Beautiful beer in every facet and regard. Clearly made with the unique, all-to-rare convergence of precocious talent and sincere love and passion. If the brewer of this beer is reading this, please know that this beer was a truly special experience. Thank you. Perfect.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

ivorywhite head leaving almost no lacing. colour is murky lemonyellow. aroma is slight funky and citric, not much going on. taste is citric sour, again some funk, little pepper in the finish. not too much going on in the aroma or taste really. rather thin body, medium carbonation. not that special imho.  bottle 75 cl

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2016 Bottle care of Vinny. Pours beautiful hazy golden with light white lacing. Aroma is light delicate sour tart character. Wonderfully simple, tart nose. Mouthfeel is light with notes of fresh, sour fruit, sourdough and lemons. Great sour saison.
Bottle. Golden pour with white head. Light fruit, Brett funk, and nice wild tones. Really funk, awesome saison.

Bottle thanks to David. Pours a cloudy orange with medium frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is strong brett, citrus, and funk. Medium mouthfeel with strong brett, citrus, light sourness and funk. Very impressive.

750mL bottle, pours a clear blonde with a medium white head. Aroma brings out farmhouse notes, citrus, and hay. Flavour brings out sharp citrusy notes, farmhouse notes, yeast, and very light funk. Very citric and sharp, finishing lightly tart and yeasty. Moderately drinkable, with a few rough edges. Doesnt stand up to the hype, but its still solid.

Bottle, thanks to ineedbeer, 03/15/2014. Pours milky golden yellow, frothy white head fades to densely-bubbled haze on the surface, a few legs of lacing left behind. Aroma is bright tangerine, pineapple, white grape and peach, tangy funkiness, dry hay. Taste brings more tangy funkiness and mellow tartness, light citric acidity with tropical fruit popping out, underlying biscuit and touch grassy bitterness coming through the end. Medium body, lively, bright sharp flavors. Excellent.
750ml bottle. Poured a cloudy yellow color with an averaged sized head. Citrus, floral, funky, yeast, fruity, and vanilla. Clean and very easy to drink.

Poured a golden Orange with a medium sized pure white head. Brett dominated the aroma with some subtle citrus notes as well. Medium bodied that was perfectly carbonated and had a wonderful dry finish. Amazing beer.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2014 Bottle received in trade that Im too egotistical to share. Thank you bytemesis for the hook up! Pours very hazy vibrant orangish yellow with a big fizzy and frothy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving some soapy lacing and trace on the glass. Smell is funky, fruity and tiny picy with crackers, barnyard, pink grapefruit juice, blood orange juice, hay, dry soil, leather, white pepper corns, lemon zest, cape gooseberries, dry wood, white grapes, pear skins and subtle hints of cereal. Taste is lightly sour, tiny bitter, fruity, earthy and tiny spicy with crackers, lemon juice, blood orange juice, sour milk, strawberry fruit yoghurt, hay, dry soil, barnyard, leather, orange zest, lemon zest, unripe pears, sour green apples, dry wood, grape skins, unripe currants, lemon grass and pepper corns. Mouthfeel is crisp, dry, tart, champagne-like and light to medium bodied. Finish is sour and funky with crackers, barnyard, lemon juice, sour milk, horseblanket, hay, dry soil, leather, lemon zest and hints of frozen strawberries and pepper corns. Wow, this really lives up to the rustic part of the SARA name. First of their beers I try and now Im keeping my fingers crossed Ill cross paths with this brewery many times in the future. Complex, tasty and incredibly refreshing sour saison. Could drink this with everything all day every day.

Several times now. Thanks to Eric for sharing the first bottle! Another bottle last week, served in a Sante Adairius tulip. Pours a nice, semi-cloudy light yellow. Bright color and good head. Nose has a bit of tart lemon along with some pineapple and tropical fruit. Light body and taste. Touch of grain. (Ive gotten some tannin in bottles in the past, however.) Light lemon and lactic through the finish. Very well done.

Bottle @ The HUGE Tasting. Gusher Alert! Hazy gold with a small head. Soft, delicate white grape jellies. Lemon and honeyed poppyseed cake. Cobwebs, attic dust. The taste is wonderfully rounded, light. Soft citrus. Brett. A touch of marshmallow and spring countryside. Soft, supple on the palate. Wonderful nuance. Delicious.

750 ml bottle shared with Prufrockstar
Im pleased to get a chance to try Sante Adairius; just starting to hear some positive buzz and of course I love the rustic ales angle. Pours the color of pineapple juice with a whipped egg white head. Intensely funky aroma compared to the Prairie Elisa5eth that preceded it, heavy latrine and some lactic aromas. The flavor follows fairly closely: lemon-juice puckering lead-in, tannic cherry pit, brett, leather, turning to a strong bitter element (more tannins?) late that seem like a flaw, as if it is trying too hard at the end. This one has a lot of interesting elements and hints at good things to come from Sante Adairius, but it doesnt really come together like Id want and up with a mid-range score.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2015 750 ml bottle, thanks to bytemesis. Ive been looking forward to this one for awhile! Pours murky gold-yellow. Carls "pineapple juice" is appropriate. Frothy white head, great lacing. Aroma: whoa funk. Ripe, juicy fruit in the aroma. Sweetness comes through with the funk -- lemon-pepper sweet tarts? Do those exist? Taste: dry (and I mean dry!) and puckering -- only lightly tart, but puckering nonetheless. After acclimating, the sweetness starts to come back. Medium body, slick texture, oily and mouth-coating, lively carbonation. Overall: nice enough, but next to eliza5beth this plays second fiddle. Glad there are folks brewing like this, at any rate!   draft at SARA 6/7/15. Murky gold pineapple juice again. Ring of bubbles. Minimal lacing. Aroma is out of this world. Apricot purée with lemon zest. Tart, citrus, pepper, mineral. Everything I want in the aroma for a tart saison. Taste is a little less inspiring (still good, but honestly a letdown). Tart, lightly botanical, toast, sour lemon curd. Once I acclimate it grows on me some, but theres something in the flavor profile that feels misplaced ... Makes me think of weeds picked from the side of a dusty highway in north Idaho. Which is not without its charm, but if that wasnt there I imagine Id be happier. Lacto almost vomity sour. Lively carbonation. Soft feel regardless (do they treat their water?). I like this more than the bottle I shared with Crow ... probably worth revisiting from time to time. Too bad I dont live in capitola(?). Upped from 3.8 to 4. On the cusp of going higher ...

75cl, new exclusive American brew Anno 2012, with Brettanomyces, thx to John for bringing this over!, complex brew, woody/floral and slightly sour/fruity, easy to drink, balanced, cloudy, small head, good brew
Gold with a white head m Nose is sour, earth, yeast, acidic, great nose. Easy palate, lightly sour, tart,acidic, smooth finish
Bottle shared by adnielsen. Pour is light and hazy, tons of funk citrus floral. Really good.
Bottle. Thanks to adnielsen for sharing. Pours a hazy golden orange color with white head. Tart, citrus, yeasty aromas and flavors. Very nice.
Nice fresh aroma with hints of Brett. No noticeable hop aroma. Straw colored and cloudy, low white head. Sour right off the bat and it lingers a bit. Dry light finish. Very nice beer just a bit sour.
Bottle @ Armins. Pours hazy yellow with a light white head. Aroma is tangy, pineapple, tropical fruits. Flavor is very tart, citrus, peach, pineapple. Nicely done

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, hazy golden orange pour with white head, aroma brought notes of white grape, apricot, peach, hints of grass, spice, slight yeasty notes, hints of tropical fruit from the brett as well, slight crackery notes. Taste is a mix of biscuit, bread, hints of grass into slight floral notes going into peach, apricot, nice earth, finishing fairly tart, slightly dry, nice fruity notes. Very tasty.
Bottle @ Armins - cloudy light yellow pour with a soft white head. Nose is tropical fruit - pineapple. Taste is really nice - soft and mellow finishing slightly bitter and sour. Excellent.

Bottle @ Armins house, courtesy of bytemesis. Pours a bright cloudy yellow appearance with a white head. Juicy tropical fruity, pineapple, peach, funky, light bubblegum, bretty aroma. Somewhat tart, really juicy, apricot/peach, pineapple, vanilla, slightly sweet, bright fruity flavor. Tasty beer.

Bottle shared at theFuck Off Massive Friday tasting, big back slaps to our host Bruce for sharing this one - where was the sound track for this one man ?03/01/14. 
Murky light orange with a thin off white covering.
Nose is tarte apricot, light spice, hay, orange pith, Brett notes, funky.
Taste comprises tarte apricot, citric tinged straw, light farmyard, pithy citrics, hay, touh of funk and subtle Brett.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, dry finish.
Decent saison but I was expecting more from this one given the ratings, didnt hold a great deal of depth, solid but no world beater for me.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 3rd January 2014Mega Tasting at Bruces pad. Thanks again to our host for this one. Very hazy gold beer, bubbly white head. Light airy palate, semi dry. Slightly sherbet sourness. Subtle floralness. Sourness resolves in to orange - lemon. Nice mix of flavours and very approachable.

Bottle thanks to Bruce and mega 2014 tasting. It pours cloudy pale orange with a small white head. The nose is funk, barnyard, some acidity, light vinegar, spice, straw, hay, apple, wood and vanilla. The taste is crisp,tart, apricot, sour peach, sherbet, hay, barnyard, some acidity and white grape skin with a crisp, dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Crisp, tart and massively drinkable. Really rather great.

Bottle shared in London during the First Tasting of the Year. Big thanks to Bruce for this special Saison. Pours hazy golden yellow with a small white head leaving very sticky lacing. Nose is sweet and appealing - loads of citrus and straw, grassy hops, mild funk. Taste is lemony and zest driven, wheat/hay/straw are all present, a touch acidic. Very prominent citrus and tropical fruits, some apricot marmalade also coming through. Nice tart to this. Very solid stuff but I think the West Ashley pips this one

Bottle shared in London during the First Tasting of the Year. Many thanks to Bruce for this special one, pours cloudy, bright yellow-gold with a frothy white head. Gorgeous aroma, lots of lemon, mango, very mild funk, hints of tangy wheat. Light sweet flavor with playful lemony sourness, mild citrus rind bitterness, a bit of hay, moderate acidity. Light bodied with average, spritzy carbonation. Super clean finish, lightly drying, with more lemony tartness, sour lemon candies, lemon rind, hints of funk, delicate balancing sweetness. Superb balance. Beautiful.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2014 12/22/2013- murky gold, puffy white head drops to a ring with collar. Hugely vinous nose, grape skin, apple skin and doughy throughout. Grapey flavor, light vanilla from barrel, soft though clearly barreled, very faint hay brett. 848417

Bottle shared by Tooch4321...thanks Adam! - Pours light golden, hazy with a thin white head. Nose is pear, stone fruit, light Brett, and a light yeastiness. Taste is fruity, light tartness, tons of peach, pear, and other stone fruit, a little yeastiness. Gentle carbonation with a medium body.
UPDATED: JUL 14, 2014 Wow. Stellar. Cosmic. This is a beer that makes you forget about every hack who puts bacon into a fermenting vessel.
bottle poured a hazy blonde yellow lively dancing white head nose was hay and grapefruit taste strong grapefruit taste some pepper and some tart hidden behind the hay middle great beer

Rating 4,900. Hazy gold pour with a white head. The aroma has a lot of lemon, biscuit malt, yeast and pepper notes. The flavor has some strong citrus notes with a lot of lemon and orange. There is also some grass and yeast, as well as some biscuit malt. As the beer warms some floral character comes out in the flavor. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Nice saison.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2013 750ml... Pours a pale hazy orange hue and topped with a thin film of soapy white head... Aroma of slightly tart farmhouse aspects almost with some oak qualities. Solid saison with more of a funky sour tinge ... More pronounced sourness than expected with a mild grain base saison feel to it. Not overwhelmingly sour, really drinkable with just shy of a medium body and semi-lively carbonation. Bit of grain on the backend with a fairly lively Brett presence.

750mL shared at Woodshop 8. Rating #6800. Pours a full haze, glowing pineapple juice. Medium, white foam. Nose is crispy pils malt, white wine barrel, pear, Brett, vanilla. Taste is soft, buoyant saltwater, Brett aeration and spice, apricot, soft pineapple, light sourness. Just a touch of lactic acidity. Pretty much saison perfection. Best beer of Woodshop 8. 8/4/9/5/17=4.3
Bottle in line for SARA from trade. Slightly funky and airy saison. Ain't got a crazy amount of flavor, some slight Meyer lemon and lemon candy. Very well carbonated. Good beer.

Pours gold/orange with a medium white head. Nose is bright stone fruits, very pleasant and tight wine barrel, well integrated wild yeast. Flavor is nicely tart upfront, segueing into some citrus, peach and pear, perhaps a faint white grape skin. Wine barrel is really tight and refined. Slight funk on the finish. Completely non-acidic, thankfully. Opens up very nicely. Second pour is murkier from the yeast but flavors are even more expressive. Really bright tart fruits, pleasantly fruit forward with integrated wine barrel, not acidic. A near perfect lightly barrel aged American saison, about as good as anything Ive had from Hill Farmstead.

pours hazy bright golden with a nice white cap, good retention and nice lacing (careful for sediment chunks). bretty dustiness, flowers, citrus, mint, spices - pink pepper, subtle and nice fruitiness - clementines, quite juicy in fact, vinous notes. moderate carbonation, light body, gently tart and floral -citrusy-dusty finish. outstanding..

Bottle. Glowing hazy gold pour with lacy white head, perfect. Lemony aroma, lots of peach, mango, chamomile, light wood notes, spicy brett profile. Flavor is tart, fruity, light fruity "sweetness" although it finishes very dry, not very hoppy. Palate is mellow and fluffy, we opened this bottle in a great time for the brett conditioning - enough to create a perception of fullness, accompanied by a nice tart dryness without overdoing anything. Beautiful.

Pours a cloudy golden with a dense white head that leaves really nice lacing. Aroma is fruity (tropical fruits, peaches and mangoes I would say) but also contains nice and fresh cereals and flowers. Taste is grainy, fruity and acid. This feels rustic to me. Mouthfeel is soft and promotes easy drinking. A really, really good (sour) saison by SARA! I could drink a lot of this!

Bottle (750 ml). From Adam, thanks! Hazy straw color with a beautiful medium white head, mostly lasting and heavy lacing. Aroma of brettanomyces, peach/mango, oak, light yeast/spices, tartness and herbal notes. Taste is slightly sweet with fruity brettanomyces, oak, peach/mango, farmhouse character, light spices and nice tartness. Medium body. Good carbonation. Dry finish. Superb Saison! Dry, refreshing and drinkable. A tad Sour for the style, but that definitely add a nice touch. Wow!

Bottle 750ml.
Pours golden with medium white head. Nice, high lacing, clinging to the glass. Aroma is of rusticity, fruits, citrus, bretts. Taste is of rusticity, fruits, slight sourness, faint sugar, citrus, bretts. Palate: Light body, dry finish. Overall: Very nice beer. Refreshing, classy. Nice sour touch. Crafty bretts.

Hazy yellow with large white head. Smell of pepper and yeast

Black pepper, yeast, pretty mute and one dimensional. Not overly imoressed by this one

(750ml bottle) Pours a cloudy yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of florals, citrus, cheese, horse blanket, mango, and dried apricots. Flavor of lemon, florals, herbaceous, stone fruit, and yeast with a moderately dry finish.

Beautiful white lace soils my glass. Golden, hazy body. 

Light, Country Time Lemonade-esque flavors melt into spicy, tangy sour base. Yeast brings its own hints of funk, yet doesn't steal the spotlight. A touch bitter at the end; brilliant finish. Could a use more pungent aroma. Perfectly carbed, and excellent all around.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2014 Aroma has a faint wisp of pickle and alcohol. Definitely a dry brett feel. Its either really complex or a total something? You decide! There are points when your like this is very interesting and then it seems unfinished. It really makes me want to eat tacos with it! It begs to be paired with food. Rename it Brett Funk Bernice! Frickin pickle! Reminds me of some sour German Hefes I have had. No sweet softness. Mild white wine like sourness.

Bottle... This beer rocks! Murky yellow pour with a small, creamy, white head. Decent retention. The nose is funky, citric and fruity - apricot and lemon. Medium-bodied and super creamy with feather-soft carbonation. The flavor is tart - bordering on sour  offering fuzzy fruits and a bready component. Short, tart, bready finish. Heres a shout out to 50belair for sharing this gem!
Bottle. Cloudy yellow pour with a white head. Sour aromas. Sour with mild stone fruit and muted orange highlights. Mild acidity and tartness. Very good mouthfeel with a good body. Impressive...

Bottle thanks 50belair - pour a yellowish w/ a nice frothy head. The nose is nice and fruit, good citrus notes - oranges, tangerines, and lemons. More citrus fruits in the tastes with a peppery feel in the end. Awesome!!!

Bottle. The pour is a murky yellow. The aroma is dish water. The taste is light and crisp. Nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2014 Bottle (Batch 2) part of an American Farmhouse/Saison tasting. Pours a hazy golden color with a sexy 2-finger thick foam. Aroma is dominated by funky, barnyard must, lemon, biscuit, hay and honey with lingering fruit skins (peaches, nectarines). It smells fruity, earthy and refreshing. Taste follows aroma, but with a more tart, cheeky presence than aroma suggests. The beer is balanced with the perfect level of must, funk and fruit esters. It is very refreshing and thirst quenching with a medium body, medium carbonation and semi-dry finish. I like that the beer is not as lemon forward as some Saisons tend to be, and not overly earthy with the addition of the brett. It is a juicy and flavorful Saison that stands out from the crowd of American farmhouse beers. Update: Have tried Batches 2-9 at this point, and with each batch its starting to get more dialed-in in terms of apricot, orange, citrus flavor. The appealing part of Bernice is its juicyness. Batch 9 so far as been the only overly floral one.

Bottle shared by Tom. Thanks, dude. Pours a well hazed golden amber hue, gentle haziness with a decent frothy whitish head. Sits atop and laces ok. Aromas are gentle white wine, oak, and bread. Some dough, mellow fruit esters and touches of earth. Some yeastiness. A bit vague. Initial is tart off the bat, white wine, tangerine and white grape, some gentle tartness. Mellow funk, bready malt. A lighter body. Middle shows some tartness, bread, a gentle dryness and sharp mellow earthy dry quality. Some mellow yeast. Backend shows fleeting barrel and fruit, still a touch tart, some mellow yeast, spice. Nice beer, good barrel front end as it tails off. Tasty
Sampled from a kind person after the FoFA. Really nice bretty, winey, tart saison that is complex and unique. Just a great brewery... gotta catchemall
Hazy yellow pour with a fluffy white head. There is a lot of fruit, tart, funk and it mixes together wonderfully. Awesome!

Bottle thanks to bird machine ! Pours a orange golden color with a finger of white foam. The nose is funky citrus, rustic yeast profile and some round stonefruit. The palate follows the nose with a nice tart fruit background that evolves from citrus pith to nectarine and traces of musty basement, funky farmhouse yeast and a long tasty refreshing finish !
Light golden pour with a medium white head. Lemony citrus funk with hints of tropical fruit and old farmy funk. Light to medium body with a refreshingly dry finish.
bottle offered by a chill bro. rustic fresh herbs. musty basement funk. complex. dry. easy drinking. tight beer.

Pretty cloudy gold with a fine head that sticks around.Very tart juicy and full of citrus. extremely dry. Lovely citrus zestiness with some barnyard tartness. not really sour, but really well done. someone throw this in a wine barrel!
sample at HF Saison fest bottle share, thanks! Great tart light saison, with some refreshing dseep complexity, another stunning beer from these guys!

750ml bottle. Hazy yellow orange with a fizzy white head. Aroma is funky earthy yeast, horse blanket, citrus, apple and light herbal. Flavor is tart upfront with a building sourness, there is some light citrus bitterness and wheat malt. Lighter body with active carbonation. This is an excellent beer, very well rounded tart saison with a nice light sourness.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2014 Bottle from Alan. Pours murky yellow gold with 2 finger head. Notes of earth, lemon skins, lemonade, salty sea, and peach brett. Good amount of carbonation to go with the medium body. Ultra dry but refreshing finish with tart citrus fruit skins coating the tongue. Another gem from Sante Adairius. Fuck batch 6 is retardedly good shared with Annie. Moved up big time, rock salt , peach, lemons. Maybe best saison out there these days.

Hazy golden-orange body, large white head, soapy lacing. Bright pear, citrus, peach, funky brett, and light pale malts. Medium bodied, lively carbonation, soft acidity, great funk. Amazingly refreshing. Demonstrates that SARA is legit.
Pours clear, aroma was sweet with slight funky farmhouse nose. Taste is slightly tart and amazing, with some barnyard and earthy tones the barrel aging has added complexity to this delicious beer.

Pour is darker hazy yellow with a white head. The nose is very nice, strong funky Saison yeast that is very earthy and mushroomy. Some juicy lemon balance and a faint dusty tones. Taste is a touch sweeter, decent yeast presence, earthy an dusty, more prevalent lemon, grassy hops, light bitterness. Medium body, light carbonation and a semi dry finish.

Pours a hazy orange juice gold with no head. Aroma of funky Brett, lacto and citrus. Taste is funky, tart, citrusy. Refreshing with no alcohol presence. This beer is in my top three saisons. Funky and tart yet really drinkable. I love this beer!

Cloudy yellowish pour, nice big white head. Oh my god this is freaking good. Its like a combo of a russian river golden sour and a wonderful belgian saison. WOW. Tart and funky and fruity and soft. UNREAL.

Apple, pear, some oakiness on the nose. Pours clear golden color, bubbly but dissipates quickly. Very delicate flavor, kind of watery thin at first but after a few seconds the complexity begins to open up on the palate. Fruity tartness, champagne-like dryness. Leaves a delicious nutty, woody aftertaste. I love the transitions in this beer: sweet to dry, fruity to nutty. Subtle and unique experience, a fantastic spin on saison style, definitely the best Sante Adairius Ive tried thus far.

Bottle. March 2013 release. Simply awesome! Basically a sour saison.. Serious mouthwatering lime nuances.. with layers of mild, lactic funk and tons of complexity. Definitely wild yeast overtones and citrus... Very well balanced, light and refreshing. Low carbonation, with a tart, dry finish. Simple and enjoyable, yet so complex. A must try. Seems to just keep getting better and better with time in the bottle.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

Thanks to Dave for this bottle. Bright orange pour with a large white head. Really excellent aroma. Crisp, dry, and yeasty. Lime zest, cracker, and a subtle tartness. Hints of apple and banana. Big lime, yeast, cracker, and lemon flavors. Subtle tartness, apple, banana, and a hint of grass. Excellent.

Thanks to Roger for hooking me up in celebration of the day when I turned from a strapping young ticker to an old, creepy, has-been ticker. In the interest of full disclosure, my granny is named Bernice so I might be biased. Thank you, granny, for allowing me to be brought into this world so that I might experience the great joy of ticking 3000+ beers. With that, here goes another tick.

This beer looks attractive to me for reasons I dont understand, sort of like the female alien in "Avatar" (I cant blame Jake for hitting that - I would). It has just the right amount of haziness in its golden-orange color with a little bit of foam and lacing. It smells great, similar to the heavenly aroma you get from putting your nose to a goat or a horse or a wet pile of hay. Barnyard with plenty of blanket, yeasty and funky with Brett notes (the yeast, not a person of that name). The flavor also has Brett (the yeast), which lends a nice restrained tartness, along with sour green apple. The palate is reasonably crisp but it could use some more carbonation. Solid and enjoyable beer overall.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2014 This rating is from a b2 bottle aged 3 months or so and the tartness really shines. the fresher the bottle, the more the yeast and "sante" house bugs character can be seen. A - pours hazy light golden orange with very low white head. S -the nose is something nice funky yeasty citrus aromas. Nice balance of all the right elements. Soft subtle funk, notes of sulfur and barnyard. Quiet bready yeasts. Prickly pineapple and fresh ripe oranges and very slight lemon rind. M - lively bright mf. Average carb. Very fruit forward, with a lingering lightly sweet almost tart end. T - very fruity up front, pineapple, fresh oranges and lemon zest. Fresh tart apples, mineral water and subtle funk. Yeasts, barnyard and bread on the palate. Dry, Fruity mineral water end. Very subtle cheese funk. O - an amazing subtle, complex very refreshing. 4.6

Bottle at home, acquired via trade. Big thanks to Felipe for this one!! Pour is hazy orange with a big white head and great lacing. Sour grain, lemon peel, biscuit, somewhat funky, light urine, straw, dough, tangerines, and white pepper in the aroma. Taste is highly refreshing - citrus, sour fruit, biscuit, a touch pepper, straw, light grass, wheat, peaches, apricots, and lemon zest with a medium sour finish. Light body with high carbonation. Highly drinkable, tart and refreshing, but has spice notes and floral characterisrics. Really nice beer. These guys are something to watch out for.

Tap, Batch #3. Pours hazy golden amber with a small white head and good lacing. Aroma is Brett, funky, bit of horse blanket, fruity, lemon. Flavor is lightly sweet, medium tart, only light funk, with a semi dry finish. Light-plus body. Very easy to drink.

Bottle. Pours a hazy almost tan golden body topped by a medium sized eggshell white head that left no lacing. Nose is bright but lightly sweet citrus, some apple, dusty earth, yeast, and a touch of brett funk. Flavor has mild spice, tart lemon, some white wine notes, with dry malt underneath it all. Any sweetness fades and funk increases as it warms. Great acidity throughout leads to drying, mouthwatering finish. Palate is medium and carbonation is crisp. Balanced, complex and so, so good.
UPDATED: JAN 27, 2014 Glass at the brewery, on tap. Pours golden, slight white head. Fresh soury saisony aroma and taste. Clean and crisp. Nice.

Pale golden/apricot color slightly hazy with fine white foam. High effervescence, spritzy. Mild astringency. Beautiful aroma hay, citrus fruit oranges and touch of grapefruit - medium full.  Acidic and sharp on the tongue, lightly sour. Mild white vinous notes. Second pour, buoyed yeast bodies, large. More barnyard aromas emerging as it warms, 51 degrees.  Admittedly off-put by the dreadlock chunk of yeast that broke free from the bottom and moved into the glass, this beer is now becoming more and very charming.   Citrus tang with a touch of phenol, clove, becoming more apparent as it warms 54 degrees. In a bright and good direction.

750mL bottle, courtesy of Tim at Sante. Thanks, Tim! I really enjoyed the Anaïs saison (sans Brett), and this was indicated to be the epitome of where Sante Adairius saison are headed. Lets hope so, because this is damn good. Pours a slightly hazy, deep-golden color; creamy, well-formed fine-bubbled white head with excellent lacing and retention. Nicely developed tartness in the aroma, showing lemony citrus, just-ripe bananas, and a touch of salinity; juicy Brett character with firm, honey-laden notes underneath. Medium body; effervescent CO2; a sturdy acidity throughout. If I had to gloss over the details and explain this beer in a phrase, it would be "peppery saison crossed with a younger lambic." Juicy Brettiness plus mouthwatering acidity, some light funk and hay-like notes, plus the firmness of a honeyed, white-pepper-focused saison; not overly dried out (but dry), not overly acidic or tart (but both); not quite like any other Brett-influenced saison Ive tried. The finish is ideal: toasty and dry, with just a hint of popcorn husks and Pils malt and pepper. Yes.

Aroma is a balanced blend of citrus and barnyard funk with a touch of goat. The citrus is very lemony. Little to no phenolics. 
Pours a cloudy straw yellow with a nice white head with good retention. 
Flavor is very lemony and refreshing with less Brett funk than the aroma had. Nice assertive bitterness and hard water make more a nice palate cleansing finish. Low phenolics in flavor as well. 
Mouthfeel is crisp and finishes dry. Not thin at all. Alcohol warmth is moderate but present without effecting aroma or flavor. No astringency. Moderately high carbonation. 
Overall this is a really nice saison and a great addition to the Sante Adairius portfolio. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On draft at the tasting room. It pours orange/golden with a small white head. The aroma has some sweet fruit candy, lemon, tropical notes, light hay and funk. The flavor has light lemon, pineapple, a little brett phenolics and pepper near the finish. Theres also some cracker like maltiness in the middle. Not very spicy or peppery. Refreshing.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2015 Batch 1: Pours an unclear straw color with a fine white head. Aromas of fresh pale malt. Smells like a brewhouse, in a good way. Light accents of citrus with subtle musty brett notes. Dry crisp malts, straw, grass, mild summer fruit. This is exactly what you want on a hot day. A complete departure from all those flabby sweet American "saisons." A really solid beer in the DuPont vein.
  
Batch 2: Pours a tangerine/pumpkin hue with a bright white head. Pronounced tartness in the aroma; lemon and kumquat, some banana. Flavor is less fruity and more bretty at this stage, with a solid funk: cheesecloth, straw, soft phenols. Citric acidity, banana pith, smooth tartness, bone-dry finish with lingering lemony aftertaste.
  
Batch 3: Pours an orange-gold color with a nice fluffy white head. Aroma is fresh grains and wort, with a touch of unripe banana and stone fruit. Flavor has a great lemony tartness throughout, teetering on the verge of sourness at times but never crossing over. Mild pale malts are barely there; this is a total yeast showcase. Secondary accents of peach pit and citrus zest. The brett is there, but not in force quite yet, due to the young age of this batch. I still get that lovely brett attenuation mouthfeel, with a pleasant dryness and maybe an occasional wisp of dusty musty funk.

Batch 4: On tap at the brewery. Peachy gold color with a white head. Big tartness on the aroma, sourish clementine notes, banana. Fresh grains, bananas and lemons, bretty chalky finish with a bit of lemon verbena. Dry and a little musty, the brett has yet to take hold. Similar to batch 3. 
 
Batch 4, again: Different keg than my last entry and actually rather different in taste. This time I get unmistakable apricot fruitiness all over the aroma and flavor, plus more significant tartness. Every time I have this beer I realize that this is what a saison ought to be. Brett, lacto, stone fruit, yogurt, dry and tart. 

Batch 5: From bottle. This batch is distinctly more blood orangey to me, but not at the expense of the nice dried apricot of the last release. Also, at only a couple months old, this beer is significantly tart, pretty sublime . This was a big hit at Ratebeer Gallery III among those I shared with. 
  
Batch 7: On tap at the brewery. Huge sour blood orange, Meyer lemon and apricot, and now Im picking up dried cherries for the first time. The midpalate complexity is huge but it resolves into such a pleasant dry simplicity. Ludicrous beer.
 
Batch 9: On tap at the brewery. Meyer lemon and apricot nose, macerated fruit in lemon juice. Flavor blends those notes back into the Brett-forward profile that I love out of young Bernice, giving a balanced beer more recognizable as a "saison" than the "sour ale" gestalt of an aged bottle for instance. 

Batch 9, again, from bottle at the brewery. Bretty apricot mimosa explosion. This is everything.
